pr_title: memoize: Change CloseableMemoize to not serialize accepts

timeline.message:
memoize: Improve CloseableMemoize to not serialize accepts

Lots of javadoc improvements and other doc updates. Some more tests.

Signed-off-by: BJ Hargrave <bj@bjhargrave.com>

timeline.bodyText: can elaborate why you're not directly writing it? It looks so strange so I assume you have reason for this?
timeline.author: pkriens

replies.bodyText: To minimize memory barriers. You need to 2 thing with the result: write to memory and also return it to the caller. If you write to memoize and then read from memoize you have both a write and read memory barrier which is unnecessary.
replies.author: bjhargrave

timeline.bodyText: this violates the contract that you call the supplier at most once ... if it throws an exception, the next get will call it again
timeline.author: pkriens

replies.bodyText: The supplier violates the contract by returning null. Unless you want to have the supplier returning null result in closing the memoizing supplier.
replies.author: bjhargrave

replies.bodyText: Well, why not just call it once to at least obey the contract?
replies.author: pkriens

replies.bodyText: If it returns null, we could declare that to be a close of the memoizeing supplier. So the memoizing supplier would enter the closed state when the wrapper supplier returns null. If that in line with what you are thinking?
replies.author: bjhargrave

replies.bodyText: We still then have the problem of what to do with the caller to our get method. Is the null then returned to him? The current state means he will get an NPE to at least alert him to the fact that the wrapped supplier returned a null. Otherwise, the caller may need to null check the result from our get.
replies.author: bjhargrave

replies.bodyText:
If we treat the wrapper supplier returning null as causing the memoized supplier to be closed, then the proper thing would be to throw an IllegalStateException since that is what would have happened if get was called on a closed memoized supplier.
I made #3973 to show this.
replies.author: bjhargrave

timeline.bodyText: what is the reason memoized is not volatile? Makes things smaller and a lot more readable?
timeline.author: pkriens

timeline.bodyText: making memoizd volatile saves a lot of this hard to read code, why doing it so complicated?
timeline.author: pkriens

replies.bodyText: The code may be a little non-straight forward but it is designed to only have a single read barrier for the normal case on get. I have review other performance tuned code which does similar work and similar techniques are used to optimize the normal case.
replies.author: bjhargrave

replies.bodyText:
it is an interesting puzzle ... my objection is that it does make the code hard to understand. It is a lot clearer now but I've always been pretty hard on simple is better unless proven otherwise. You lately seem to more and more go to small optimizations over readability.
Just for theory, let me try to come up with something that is more readable and only has one read barrier for the common case.
Did you introduce the StampedLock (first time I run into it...) because you can then have a read lock on the accept? Or is there some other advantage over a synchronized block?
replies.author: pkriens

replies.bodyText:
Did you introduce the StampedLock (first time I run into it...) because you can then have a read lock on the accept?

I used it for the read/write lock support which is much simpler then ReentrantReadWriteLock. Some actions (initial get and close) need exclusive (write) locks while accept needs a non-exclusive (read) lock to hold off close. The accept method can now get the write lock if needed and downgrade to the read lock before calling the consumer.
StampedLocks are much faster than ReentrantReadWriteLocks but they are not reentrant (which we did not need) and also have some other limitations (which were not an issue for this usage).
replies.author: bjhargrave

replies.bodyText: I noticed StampedLocks are not reentrant. So if accept calls accept, we have a deadlock. Shouldn't we have a timeout to break this?
replies.author: pkriens
